ai.summary: Dava Way is a challenging long-distance trail in the UK, approximately 97.1 km in length, following a former railway line and delivering varied scenery from rural landscapes to woodland and riverside sections. Its hard rating reflects the distance and exposure to weather changes.
ai.terrain_summary: Primarily an old railway alignment converted for walkers, with long straight stretches and gentle grades. Surfaces range from compact gravel and surfaced paths to grassy tracks; expect mud after rain and occasional road crossings. The route can be exposed to wind and weather, making navigation and stamina important over multiple days.
ai.safety_notes: Plan for multi-day travel with daylight and route planning. The distance makes this a demanding hike; carry a map and compass (or GPS), a charged phone, and a clear communication plan. Check weather forecasts before setting out; UK conditions can change rapidly. Wear durable boots, stay hydrated, and bring layers for rain and cold. Inform someone of your itinerary and expected finish times; know access points for escape or bailout if needed. Have backup lighting and an emergency plan for overnight stops.
recommended_gear: Headlamp or flashlight with extra batteries
Fully charged phone and portable power bank
First aid kit and emergency blanket
Emergency bivy or lightweight shelter (for multi-day trips)
Duct tape, spare laces, and basic repair tools
Dry bag or waterproof covers for gear
ai.best_seasons: Spring to autumn (roughly March to October) is generally best for longer daylight hours and more reliable weather; winter hiking is possible with careful planning, but conditions can be harsh and days are shorter.
